title: Famous Playwrights
description: From Shakespeare to Arthur Miller, how well do you know the masters of the stage?

questions.question: Which playwright wrote 'Death of a Salesman' and 'The Crucible'?
questions.explanation: Arthur Miller wrote 'Death of a Salesman' (1949) and 'The Crucible' (1953). He is considered one of the greatest American playwrights of the 20th century.

questions.question: Tennessee Williams is best known for which play about a faded Southern belle?
options: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof
questions.explanation: 'A Streetcar Named Desire' (1947) tells the story of Blanche DuBois, who arrives at her sister's home in New Orleans. The original Broadway production starred Marlon Brando as Stanley Kowalski.

questions.question: How many plays are attributed to William Shakespeare?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare wrote approximately 37 plays (the exact number is debated), along with 154 sonnets and several longer poems. His works span comedies, tragedies, and histories.

questions.question: Which Norwegian playwright wrote 'A Doll's House' and 'Hedda Gabler'?
questions.explanation: Henrik Ibsen is often called the 'father of modern drama.' 'A Doll's House' (1879) shocked audiences with its portrayal of a woman leaving her husband and children to find herself.

questions.question: Which Russian playwright wrote 'The Cherry Orchard' and 'Three Sisters'?
questions.explanation: Anton Chekhov revolutionized theater with his subtle, psychologically rich dramas. 'The Cherry Orchard' (1904) explores the decline of the Russian aristocracy and was his final play.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Waiting for Godot,' a landmark of absurdist theater?
questions.explanation: Samuel Beckett wrote 'Waiting for Godot' in French, first performed in 1953. The play depicts two men waiting endlessly for someone named Godot who never arrives, and is considered a masterpiece of the Theater of the Absurd.

questions.question: Which ancient Greek playwright wrote 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone'?
questions.explanation: Sophocles (c. 496-406 BC) wrote over 120 plays, of which only seven survive complete. 'Oedipus Rex' is often cited as the perfect example of Greek tragedy.

questions.question: Oscar Wilde wrote which witty comedy about mistaken identities and the name Ernest?
questions.explanation: 'The Importance of Being Earnest' (1895) is a farcical comedy in which two men each pretend to be named Ernest to win the affections of two women. It is considered Wilde's masterpiece.

questions.question: Which German playwright developed 'epic theater' and wrote 'The Threepenny Opera'?
questions.explanation: Bertolt Brecht developed 'epic theater,' which used techniques to distance the audience emotionally so they would think critically about social issues rather than just feel emotions.

questions.question: Eugene O'Neill, America's first great playwright, won how many Pulitzer Prizes for Drama?
questions.explanation: Eugene O'Neill won four Pulitzer Prizes for Drama and the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1936. His masterwork 'Long Day's Journey into Night' was published posthumously.

questions.question: Which French playwright wrote 'Tartuffe' and 'The Misanthrope' in the 17th century?
questions.explanation: Molière (Jean-Baptiste Poquelin) was the master of French comedy. 'Tartuffe' (1664), which satirized religious hypocrisy, was initially banned by King Louis XIV under pressure from the church.

questions.question: Which playwright wrote 'A Raisin in the Sun,' the first play by a Black woman produced on Broadway?
questions.explanation: Lorraine Hansberry's 'A Raisin in the Sun' (1959) follows a Black family's struggles on Chicago's South Side. She was just 29 when it premiered, making her the youngest American playwright to win the New York Drama Critics' Circle Award.

questions.question: Which Shakespeare play features the line 'To be, or not to be, that is the question'?
questions.explanation: Prince Hamlet speaks this famous soliloquy in Act 3, Scene 1 of Shakespeare's 'Hamlet' (c. 1600). The play is Shakespeare's longest and one of the most performed works in world literature.

questions.question: Which Irish playwright wrote 'Pygmalion,' later adapted into the musical 'My Fair Lady'?
questions.explanation: George Bernard Shaw wrote 'Pygmalion' in 1912 about a professor who transforms a Cockney flower girl into a lady. Shaw won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1925.

questions.question: Which playwright created 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'
questions.explanation: Edward Albee's 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?' (1962) depicts a bitter evening of psychological warfare between a married couple and their guests. It won the Tony Award for Best Play.
